dt.t: Two other deities from the vast {wi}pantheon{/wi} of ancient Mesopotamia deserve special mention. These are the sinister powers of the underworld, Ereshkigal and Nergal.

Climbing the crumbling stone steps, I noticed a fat monkey sitting on the outside wall of the temple, next to a stone carving of Rangda, the witch and troublemaker in the complex Balinese {wi}pantheon{/wi} of frightening demons and protective demigods.

dt: {bc}a temple dedicated to all the gods

Generic use of this sense is rare. The capitalized form {it}Pantheon{/it} is the common name of a domed temple in Rome that was begun in 27 {sc}b.c.{/sc} by Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa and completely rebuilt by the emperor Hadrian circa 118-128 {sc}a.d.{/sc} It was dedicated in 609 {sc}a.d.{/sc} as the Church of Santa Maria Rotonda, or Santa Maria ad Martyres.
{bc}a group of illustrious or notable persons or things

dt.t: In his mid-seventies, Robert Redford is still hanging on to the good looks and easy charm that have earned him a firm place in the {wi}pantheon{/wi} of American film legends …
Robert Strauss also occupies a place in the {wi}pantheon{/wi} of lawyer-lobbyist money raisers …
It was a strike of such purity and importance it immediately earned a place in the {wi}pantheon{/wi} of the game's greatest 72nd hole shots …
Of the historic, formal French Quarter restaurants—a {wi}pantheon{/wi} that includes Antoine's, Galatoire's and Brennan's—Arnaud's was the first to reopen, on Dec. 1.

dt: {bc}a building serving as the burial place of or containing memorials to the famous dead of a nation

Generic use of this sense is rare. The capitalized form {it}Pantheon{/it} is used as or in the English-language names of various buildings around the world that are memorials to or resting places for the dead, perhaps most famously the Pantheon (French: {it}Panthéon{/it}) of Paris, which was begun circa 1757 by the architect Jacques-Germain Soufflot as the Church of Sainte-Geneviève.

et: Middle English {it}Panteon{/it}, a temple at Rome, from Latin {it}Pantheon{/it}, from Greek {it}pantheion{/it} temple of all the gods, from neuter of {it}pantheios{/it} of all gods, from {it}pan-{/it} + {it}theos{/it} god
shortdef: the gods of a people; especially : the officially recognized gods
a temple dedicated to all the gods
a group of illustrious or notable persons or things
